description:
# Overview #

[SimulationIO](https://github.com/eschnett/SimulationIO) is a data format created by @eschnett for relativistic simulations that is designed to be extremely self-describing. SimulationIO uses a category theory graph to describe all parameters of the simulation, including manifold properties and topology, coordinate system, tensorial structure, coordinate systems and tangent spaces, etc. We have a converter from Carpet's native IO format to SimulationIO and we'd like to use SimulationIO as a target for the Einstein Toolkit and Carpet.

This pull request provides a reader for SimulationIO in yt that can handle many of the situations one encounters in the Einstein Toolkit. There are, unfortunately, missing features. However, I believe that SimulationIO and the frontend are now sufficiently mature that they can be released for Einstein Toolkit users to try and make use of.

## Getting Everything to Work ##

To use the frontend, you must:

* Install a version of yt with the frontend (obviously)
*  install HDF5 version 1.8.16 or higher
* Install the release-0.1 version of SimulationIO as per the instructions [here](https://github.com/eschnett/SimulationIO/tree/release-0.1).

### Living Documents ###

* This file is my to-do list. I will keep it up to date:
```
yt/frontends/simulationio/TODO.md
```

## Current Status ##

The frontend can successfully read Cartesian cell-centred AMR data. However the Einstein Toolkit supports semi-structured meshes via both a multiblock and discontinuous Galerkin infrastructure. It also supports vertex-centred AMR. Sadly, none of these features are compatible with the frontend.

## Wish List ##

These are my long term goals, in rough order of priority.

* vertex-centred data
* Support for the Einstein Toolk's [multipatch infrastructure](http://llamacode.bitbucket.org/)
* Support for the Einstein Toolkit's [operator-based discontinuous Galerkin methods](http://arxiv.org/abs/1604.00075)
title: A SimulationIO Frontend

content.raw: In general we avoid using bare excepts, since it can lead to unintended consequences. See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21553327/why-is-except-pass-a-bad-programming-practice for a detailed explanation.
content.html: In general we avoid using bare excepts, since it can lead to unintended consequences. See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21553327/why-is-except-pass-a-bad-programming-practice for a detailed explanation.

content.raw: this commented import can be deleted
content.html: this commented import can be deleted

content.raw: This needs to be `except (IOErrror, ImportError)`, in case netCDF4 isn't importable.
content.html: This needs to be except (IOErrror, ImportError), in case netCDF4 isn't importable.

content.raw: Here as well, but in case `h5py` isn't importable.
content.html: Here as well, but in case h5py isn't importable.

content.raw: @hyschive any chance you can look this over? You were the most recent person to write a new frontend, so hopefully you have possible issues fresh in your mind.
content.html: Hsi-Yu Schive any chance you can look this over? You were the most recent person to write a new frontend, so hopefully you have possible issues fresh in your mind.

content.raw: No problem. I'll look into it :)
content.html: No problem. I'll look into it :)

content.raw:
Jonah

   - install a current version of HDF5 (the one provided by Ubuntu, for
   example, is too old).
   - Install the release-0.1 version of SimulationIO as per the
   instructions here
   <https://github.com/eschnett/SimulationIO/tree/release-0.1>.

Regarding these two items:

- Why is a current version of HDF5 required? Is this something that could
be worked around? This requirement was fine for the development version of
SimulationIO, but if it is now exposed to a larger audience, compatibility
becomes more important.
- We need to ensure that SimulationIO remains sufficiently compatible with
the data formats produced by version 0.1 of SimulationIO. Since this is
version 0.1, we have some leeway, but we shouldn't be breaking things
accidentally either. We should think about a mechanism (e.g. regression
tests) to ensure compatibility. Maybe storing a few files produces by 0.1
and ensuring we can continue to read them would be a way to go forward.

What does it mean for me to be a reviewer of this pull request? Do all
reviewers have to accept, or only one?
content.html:
Jonah

  • install a current version of HDF5 (the one provided by Ubuntu, for example, is too old).
  • Install the release-0.1 version of SimulationIO as per the instructions here https://github.com/eschnett/SimulationIO/tree/release-0.1.

Regarding these two items:

  • Why is a current version of HDF5 required? Is this something that could be worked around? This requirement was fine for the development version of SimulationIO, but if it is now exposed to a larger audience, compatibility becomes more important.
  • We need to ensure that SimulationIO remains sufficiently compatible with the data formats produced by version 0.1 of SimulationIO. Since this is version 0.1, we have some leeway, but we shouldn't be breaking things accidentally either. We should think about a mechanism (e.g. regression tests) to ensure compatibility. Maybe storing a few files produces by 0.1 and ensuring we can continue to read them would be a way to go forward.

What does it mean for me to be a reviewer of this pull request? Do all reviewers have to accept, or only one?

content.raw: Three people need to review and approve the pill request before it can be accepted. If someone adds you as a reviewer it just means they think you would be a good person to do so, but you're under no obligation.
content.html: Three people need to review and approve the pill request before it can be accepted. If someone adds you as a reviewer it just means they think you would be a good person to do so, but you're under no obligation.

content.raw:
@eschnett,

It's been too long, so I no longer remember what problems I had with HDF5 versions. The version that failed was 1.8.11. The version I installed successfully was 1.8.17. I'll try compiling against 1.8.11 and see if I can't figure out what feature is missing.

Regarding forward compatibility, yes I agree. I have three such files which I use for the testing infrastructure in yt and provided to @xarthisius for yt's integration server. Perhaps we could use the same files in our own upstream testing infrastructure?

As a last minute thought, perhaps we should make one more change to release-0.1: we could add a "version" attribute to the root of the hdf5 file, saying it is a SimulationIO file version 0.1. I could regenerate the files with this property and give them to Kacper. It might make adding new features easier, since we'll be able to have the API check if they're present in the file.
content.html:
Erik Schnetter,

It's been too long, so I no longer remember what problems I had with HDF5 versions. The version that failed was 1.8.11. The version I installed successfully was 1.8.17. I'll try compiling against 1.8.11 and see if I can't figure out what feature is missing.

Regarding forward compatibility, yes I agree. I have three such files which I use for the testing infrastructure in yt and provided to Kacper Kowalik for yt's integration server. Perhaps we could use the same files in our own upstream testing infrastructure?

As a last minute thought, perhaps we should make one more change to release-0.1: we could add a "version" attribute to the root of the hdf5 file, saying it is a SimulationIO file version 0.1. I could regenerate the files with this property and give them to Kacper. It might make adding new features easier, since we'll be able to have the API check if they're present in the file.

content.raw:
It seems that the oldest version of HDF5 I can get to work is 1.8.16, which was released November 2015. The problems I encountered are listed below:

1. In version 1.8.11, there is no H5Location abstract base class. This is used deep within SimulationIO's H5Helpers. This abstract base class was introduced in version 1.8.12.
2. In version 1.8.12, there is no constructor for H5Files based on location ids. We use this constructor, which is introduced in 1.8.15. This piece of the API is hidden from the official doxygen documentation. So I'm not really sure we should be using it in the first place. (It makes no sense to me for this constructor to be private or low-level. It's an interface between the C and C++ APIs. Why on earth is it so obscure?)
3. Version 1.8.15 seems to be suffering from some sort of nasty bug when compiled with the C++11 standard. I encounter hundreds of lines of errors similar to those encountered in [this stackoverflow question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19043109/gcc-4-8-1-combining-c-code-with-c11-code). Perhaps the headers or the build system are doing something that they shouldn't be.

What do you think, @eschnett ? Should we stick with the requirement of 1.8.16? Or should we try to make SimulationIO compatible with an earlier version?
content.html:
It seems that the oldest version of HDF5 I can get to work is 1.8.16, which was released November 2015. The problems I encountered are listed below:

  1. In version 1.8.11, there is no H5Location abstract base class. This is used deep within SimulationIO's H5Helpers. This abstract base class was introduced in version 1.8.12.
  2. In version 1.8.12, there is no constructor for H5Files based on location ids. We use this constructor, which is introduced in 1.8.15. This piece of the API is hidden from the official doxygen documentation. So I'm not really sure we should be using it in the first place. (It makes no sense to me for this constructor to be private or low-level. It's an interface between the C and C++ APIs. Why on earth is it so obscure?)
  3. Version 1.8.15 seems to be suffering from some sort of nasty bug when compiled with the C++11 standard. I encounter hundreds of lines of errors similar to those encountered in this stackoverflow question. Perhaps the headers or the build system are doing something that they shouldn't be.

What do you think, Erik Schnetter ? Should we stick with the requirement of 1.8.16? Or should we try to make SimulationIO compatible with an earlier version?

content.raw:
HDF5's C++ interface is designed in a strange way. I mostly like it because the destructors automatically close all the respective HDF5 objects, which is otherwise tedious, and is exactly why C++ destructors were invented. I've dreamed about rewriting the HDF5 C++ interface myself.

Maybe there's a simple solution -- a wrapper type for hid_t with a constructor that calls the respective "close" function, and a simple way to extract the actual hid_t when calling the C API.
content.html:
HDF5's C++ interface is designed in a strange way. I mostly like it because the destructors automatically close all the respective HDF5 objects, which is otherwise tedious, and is exactly why C++ destructors were invented. I've dreamed about rewriting the HDF5 C++ interface myself.

Maybe there's a simple solution -- a wrapper type for hid_t with a constructor that calls the respective "close" function, and a simple way to extract the actual hid_t when calling the C API.

content.raw:
That certainly seems less tedious than using the bare C API.

My feeling is that hid_t wants to be a proxy for an object anyway and thus HDF5 very naturally fits into an object oriented paradigm. But as I discovered today, yes... they've done some very weird things.
content.html:
That certainly seems less tedious than using the bare C API.

My feeling is that hid_t wants to be a proxy for an object anyway and thus HDF5 very naturally fits into an object oriented paradigm. But as I discovered today, yes... they've done some very weird things.

content.html: I don't see this parameter set elsewhere. Does simulationio always assume non-periodic boundary condition?

content.raw: These units are hard coded. Is there any chance that the datasets are actually in a different unit system? In addition, to support the *units_override* functionality when loading data, I think these units need to be set by *setdefaultattr*. Please refer to other frontends. On the other hands, if the units in simulationio are always fixed and should never be modified by users, you might want to issue a warning or error message if *units_override* gets set.
content.html: These units are hard coded. Is there any chance that the datasets are actually in a different unit system? In addition, to support the units_override functionality when loading data, I think these units need to be set by setdefaultattr. Please refer to other frontends. On the other hands, if the units in simulationio are always fixed and should never be modified by users, you might want to issue a warning or error message if units_override gets set.

content.raw:
SimulationIO doesn't specify periodicity at the moment, so it must be provided by the user.

Often times, SimulationIO explicitly provides the ghost zones, which must be cut out. It's on my to-do list to have yt read these in instead of generating it's own in these cases. If SimulationIO provides its own ghost zones, the periodicity parameter should always be set to false.

Another thing on my to-do list is to specify more complicated symmetry properties in SimulationIO, such as rotational or reflection symmetry. @ngoldbaum and I talked about that a while back. I think he has a mock implementation of this feature in yt somewhere. :)
content.html:
SimulationIO doesn't specify periodicity at the moment, so it must be provided by the user.

Often times, SimulationIO explicitly provides the ghost zones, which must be cut out. It's on my to-do list to have yt read these in instead of generating it's own in these cases. If SimulationIO provides its own ghost zones, the periodicity parameter should always be set to false.

Another thing on my to-do list is to specify more complicated symmetry properties in SimulationIO, such as rotational or reflection symmetry. Nathan Goldbaum and I talked about that a while back. I think he has a mock implementation of this feature in yt somewhere. :)

content.raw: Yes, there's a chance that the default units could be different. At the moment, that's unlikely, but I can see it changing in the future. I hadn't paid attention to that. I'll look into `setdefaultattr`. Can you suggest a frontend to look at?
content.html: Yes, there's a chance that the default units could be different. At the moment, that's unlikely, but I can see it changing in the future. I hadn't paid attention to that. I'll look into setdefaultattr. Can you suggest a frontend to look at?

content.html: Will do.

content.html: Better yet, I'll move the check to here and raise an error.

content.raw: It hasn't necessarily been set. It can be set explicitly by the user. But if it is not, then it is reconstructed in this line. Essentially if `_setup_coordinates_no_bbox` is called, this line is necessary. If `_setup_coordinates_bbox` is called instead, it's not necessary. But it felt cleaner to call it here in either case. It's a projective operation, so it can't do any harm and I like sanity checks.
content.html: It hasn't necessarily been set. It can be set explicitly by the user. But if it is not, then it is reconstructed in this line. Essentially if _setup_coordinates_no_bbox is called, this line is necessary. If _setup_coordinates_bbox is called instead, it's not necessary. But it felt cleaner to call it here in either case. It's a projective operation, so it can't do any harm and I like sanity checks.

content.raw: Shouldn't the question be "why is this check superfluous?"
content.html: Shouldn't the question be "why is this check superfluous?"

content.raw:
We try to avoid bare asserts like this in yt; if this fails, a number of things have gone intensely wrong, and an `assert` at this point will provide essentially no useful information to the user.

If this needs to be done, it should be done by checking this conditional and raising a subclass of `YTException` that is defined in `yt/utilities/exceptions.py`.
content.html:
We try to avoid bare asserts like this in yt; if this fails, a number of things have gone intensely wrong, and an assert at this point will provide essentially no useful information to the user.

If this needs to be done, it should be done by checking this conditional and raising a subclass of YTException that is defined in yt/utilities/exceptions.py.

content.raw: Good point about the bare assert. I'm apparently still in the mindset of batch applications where you want to fail early and hard, and am forgetting that that's no good in an interactive environment.
content.html: Good point about the bare assert. I'm apparently still in the mindset of batch applications where you want to fail early and hard, and am forgetting that that's no good in an interactive environment.

content.html: Sorry if my question is confusing. I definitely support these sanity checks, and I'm just curious if there is any special concern about this check. Perhaps some comments on the code will be helpful for future developers. Also, thanks Matt Turk for the comments!

Do you think it's worthwhile to add some instructions on how to actually install SimulationIO and convert a carpet or einstein toolkit data to that format? Maybe there's a place in the SimulationIO docs you can link to that describes how to do that?

Operationally, it should be clear from reading this document how to take some arbitrary Einstein Toolkit or Carpet data that the frontend you've written should support and convert it, then load it with yt.
